title: What Factors Influence Your Fluid Needs?

sections.content: We often hear the advice: “Drink eight glasses of water a day!” — but in reality, it’s not that simple. Scientists have long abandoned this universal rule in favor of a more flexible approach: everyone’s fluid needs are unique and depend on many factors.

sections.subtitle: Body size and individual traits
sections.content: Men usually drink more than women, simply because on average their bodies are larger and require more water. Age also plays a role: both children and older adults may not feel thirst as clearly, so it’s harder for them to “catch” the right moment to drink.

sections.subtitle: Physical activity
sections.content: If you run, go to the gym, or simply move a lot throughout the day, your fluid requirements are higher. During activity, we lose water through sweat, and it needs to be replenished. Otherwise, fatigue, dizziness, and even dehydration can occur.

sections.subtitle: Climate and temperature
sections.content: Hot weather accelerates sweating, and the body loses fluids faster. But in winter, needs can also increase: dry indoor air and temperature changes cause additional fluid loss as well.

sections.subtitle: Special conditions
sections.content: Pregnant and breastfeeding women require more water to support both themselves and their baby. Illness also makes a difference — especially with fever, vomiting, or diarrhea — the body loses fluids much faster, and replenishing them becomes crucial.

sections.subtitle: Diet
sections.content: Spicy and salty foods increase thirst: salt retains water in the body but at the same time stimulates the desire to drink more. The type of diet also matters — for example, a high-protein diet increases fluid requirements.

sections.subtitle: Not just water
sections.content: Around 20% of daily fluid intake comes from food — especially vegetables, fruits, and soups. Drinks count too: tea, coffee, milk. Modern research confirms that moderate caffeine intake does not dehydrate the body, so your morning cup of coffee definitely “counts.”

sections.subtitle: How to know if you’re drinking enough?
sections.content: The main guide is how you feel. If you rarely feel thirsty, have good energy, your skin isn’t overly dry, and your head doesn’t feel heavy — you’re probably drinking enough. But if you notice fatigue, dry mouth, or trouble focusing, it’s a sign to pour yourself a glass of water.

title: How Does Water Help Keep Your Brain in Shape?

sections.content: You’ve probably noticed that by the middle of the day, thoughts seem to slow down, focus slips away, and even simple tasks take more effort. Fatigue, stress, or lack of sleep may play a role, but there’s another factor we often overlook — not getting enough water.

sections.subtitle: Water as Fuel for the Brain
sections.content: We usually think about drinking water for healthy skin, digestion, or overall well-being. But water is also vital fuel for the brain. About 75% of its structure is made up of water, and even a slight imbalance can affect mental clarity, memory, and mood.

sections.subtitle: What Happens When Water Is Lacking
sections.content: A decrease in fluid levels as small as 1–2% can already influence cognitive performance. It doesn’t mean that a person becomes “less intelligent.” Rather, the brain, like any complex system, works best when everything is in balance. With too little water, it becomes harder to maintain focus, distraction increases, fatigue builds up faster, and irritability may appear without any obvious reason.

sections.subtitle: What Research Shows
sections.content: These effects have been documented in scientific studies. For example, a review published in The Journal of Nutrition (2012) found that even mild dehydration can slow down information processing, weaken short-term memory, and make concentration more difficult.

sections.subtitle: Why Thirst Is a Late Signal
sections.content: The brain reacts to water shortage even before you feel thirsty. By the time the body sends the “I need water” signal, it has already been working below its optimal state.

sections.subtitle: What This Means in Practice
sections.content: To keep your brain in shape, it’s better to drink water regularly throughout the day rather than only when thirst appears. Keep a bottle nearby, take small sips during breaks, and make sure to drink before tasks that require focus. This simple habit can help you maintain energy, mental clarity, and productivity.

title: Why Is the Brain So Sensitive to Water?

sections.content: We often think of water as just a “filler” for the body. In reality, it plays a central role in how the brain works. It helps brain cells maintain their shape and volume, supports blood flow that delivers oxygen and nutrients, and keeps the water–electrolyte balance stable so neurons can transmit signals effectively.

sections.subtitle: What Happens with Deficiency
sections.content: When fluids decrease, the brain literally changes its shape. MRI scans show that brain tissue can temporarily “shrink.” Blood flow slows, electrolyte balance is disrupted, and neurons become less efficient.

sections.subtitle: How It Feels
sections.content: Imagine music recorded at lower quality. The melody is still there, but the clarity and richness are gone. The same happens with the brain: thinking doesn’t disappear, but focus and speed decline.

sections.subtitle: What This Means for Us
sections.content: Even mild dehydration can affect cognitive functions. To keep your brain sharp, it’s important not to wait for strong thirst signals — instead, drink small amounts regularly throughout the day.

Some people think it’s unnecessary to drink during workouts — that you can simply rehydrate afterward. But research shows that hydration is directly tied to how well the body performs under physical stress.

sections.subtitle: Why It Matters
sections.content: As you move, your body heats up, and to stay cool it releases sweat. Along with sweat, you lose not just water but also key electrolytes — sodium, potassium, magnesium. These are essential for muscles and the nervous system to function smoothly. Even mild dehydration can reduce endurance and make movements less precise.

sections.subtitle: How It Feels
sections.content: Losing as little as 2% of body weight through fluids already reduces reaction speed and increases fatigue. According to the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM), this level of dehydration impairs coordination and makes usual exercises feel much harder. In hot environments or during intense sessions, dehydration can even become a health risk.

sections.subtitle: What Research Shows
sections.content: Studies published in the Journal of Applied Physiology highlight that athletes who stay hydrated maintain focus longer, control their movements better, and recover faster after exercise. By contrast, insufficient water intake leads to more mistakes and a stronger sense of fatigue.

sections.subtitle: Practical Tips
sections.content: The best approach is to sip small amounts of water regularly throughout your workout rather than drinking a lot at once afterward. Having a glass of water about an hour before exercise also helps.
Many people assume that the “two liters a day” rule refers only to plain water. In reality, the body receives fluids from many different sources, and all of them matter.

sections.subtitle: Drinks Beyond Water
sections.content: Tea, coffee, juices, milk, and even cocoa also contribute to daily hydration. For a long time, coffee and tea were thought to “dehydrate” the body because of caffeine. But modern research — including a study published in PLOS ONE (2014) — has shown that moderate caffeine intake does not negatively affect fluid balance. So yes, your morning cup of coffee does count.

sections.subtitle: Food as a Source of Water
sections.content: Roughly 20% of our daily fluid intake comes from food rather than a glass. Soups, fruits, vegetables, and even yogurt are rich in water. For example, watermelon and cucumbers are composed of about 90–95% water. This means a balanced diet also helps you stay hydrated.

sections.subtitle: Practical Perspective
sections.content: It’s not useful to divide drinks into “right” and “wrong.” A good approach is to make water your main source while recognizing that tea, juice, or dairy products also contribute. The key is to pay attention to how you feel and remember that hydration is the sum of many foods and drinks together.

sections.subtitle: Drop in Energy
sections.content: Even mild dehydration can cause fatigue and reduce performance. Research, including a review in Nutrients (2019), shows that losing as little as 1–2% of body weight through fluids has a clear impact on energy levels.

sections.subtitle: Difficulty Concentrating
sections.content: Since the brain is about 75% water, it’s highly sensitive to dehydration. People often notice feeling more distracted, struggling to focus, or reacting more slowly when they don’t drink enough.

sections.subtitle: Mood and Well-Being
sections.content: Lack of water is often reflected in irritability, headaches, or slight dizziness. These symptoms are easy to mistake for stress or tiredness, but they’re frequently linked to hydration.

sections.subtitle: What This Means in Practice
sections.content: Don’t wait until you’re very thirsty. If you notice an energy dip, problems with focus, or unexplained irritability, try drinking a glass of water. Often that’s enough to feel better and restore mental clarity.

title: The Role of Water During a Cold

sections.content: When we get sick, doctors almost always recommend: “Drink more fluids.” It sounds simple, but there are strong physiological reasons behind this advice.

sections.subtitle: Supporting Temperature Regulation
sections.content: With fever, the body loses more water through sweat and breathing. Extra fluids help regulate heat exchange and lower the risk of overheating.

sections.subtitle: Restoring the Mucous Membranes
sections.content: During a runny nose or cough, mucous membranes dry out quickly. Adequate hydration keeps them moist, makes breathing easier, and supports mucus clearance.

sections.subtitle: Reducing Fatigue
sections.content: Even mild dehydration increases feelings of weakness. Research, including a review in the Journal of Clinical Medicine (2020), confirms that maintaining hydration supports energy levels and helps the immune system function more effectively.

sections.subtitle: What This Means in Practice
sections.content: During a cold, it’s important to drink regularly in small amounts. Water, warm herbal teas, and broths are especially helpful. Very sweet or carbonated drinks are best limited, as they may hinder recovery.

sections.subtitle: Impact on the Brain and Cognition
sections.content: Even a 2% drop in body fluids can impair memory, focus, and reaction speed. Prolonged dehydration increases fatigue, lowers mood, and makes irritability more likely. Research published in Nutrients (2019) highlights these cognitive effects.

sections.subtitle: Strain on the Heart and Blood Vessels
sections.content: With less water, blood becomes thicker, forcing the heart to work harder. Blood pressure may fluctuate, and in hot conditions or during exercise this raises the risk of overheating and dizziness.

sections.subtitle: Kidney and Digestive Issues
sections.content: Water is essential for filtering waste products. Without enough, the kidneys are put under strain, and the risk of kidney stones rises. Digestion also slows down — dehydration often leads to constipation.

sections.subtitle: Rising Body Temperature
sections.content: Dehydrated bodies can’t cool down efficiently. Sweat loss outpaces replenishment, which can lead to overheating or even heat stroke.
